The gameplay of Akin is so simple that you only need a short gameplay video to get it right away. Filling an entire map of squares with the same colour is calming and oddly satisfying. My interest is kept with all the 96 puzzles including time trials. There are some flaws that if taken care of, could have made the experience more pleasant. I would have liked a retry option after completing a puzzle. You normally only get that option whilst you‚Äôre doing a puzzle. After completing it you either select next puzzle or go to the main menu. The timer starts the moment you select a puzzle. It would have been better to start with the timer as soon as you make your first move. This is especially handy for time trials. Lastly, a redo move button might sound nice but I‚Äôm not sure it‚Äôs possible with the way the gameplay works. You use the mouse to quickly draw lines. I‚Äôm not sure how one move can be determined through one long straight line. 

The graphics are functional. There is one music in the entire game that is fine but gets old after a while. It took around 10 hours to get the achievements. They‚Äôre all about completing the puzzles in both modes plus completing time trials within 15 minutes. The 15 minutes one was fun, especially since there is an in-game timer to know how far you are. 

The game is not going to rock your world. It‚Äôs not the best at anything but what‚Äôs there is enjoyable enough in short bursts. It only costs ‚Ç¨1 and it‚Äôs worth that price if you‚Äôre looking to kill some time with a simple puzzle game.

review: This game blows. I'm a big fan of puzzle games but this is some of the least fun I've had playing games in recent memory. The puzzle system isn't anything to write home about, it's fine. But there is so little polish. The animations and art is boring and bland, the music is repetitive and not particularly interesting, and the controls are terrible. Its genuinely commendable that they messed up a click and drag control scheme. Go too fast and your mouse won't move and its so easy to just slip up and have to restart from the beginning which is fine at first but in those longer maps where its 30+ seconds to complete its just a hassle, especially with (as far as I could tell) no restart hotkey. You spend so long on the main menu, backing out of a puzzle puts you back at the main menu, instead of the group you're in. Just zero polish and no QOL. Its cheap which is nice but man its not worth anyone's time when there are so many better puzzle games out there

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

review:
Ah, the labyrinthine simplicity of Akin, a puzzle game that masquerades as a cerebral exercise in chromatic manipulation. In a world brimming with digital distractions, Akin beckons you to embark on a journey that is seemingly straightforward ‚Äì draw a line, change some colors, make things akin. Yet, within this ostensible simplicity lies a maddening dance of hues and lines that would make even the most stoic of philosophers question the very fabric of their existence.

As you traverse the 96 puzzles in "Normal"-mode, you'll find yourself entangled in the deceptive elegance of one continuous line. It's like navigating the convoluted corridors of existential ennui, each tile a metaphor for life's capricious twists and turns. The transition from orange to blue, or vice versa, becomes a symbolic metamorphosis akin to the shifting shades of human experience. It's as if the game is whispering, "Life is fleeting, and so are these colors ‚Äì make them akin before the inevitable descent into the void."

Enter the "Time"-mode, a realm where the ticking clock mocks your futile attempts at mastery. Here, the puzzles, like the relentless march of time, demand swifter strokes and more decisive choices. It's a commentary on the ephemeral nature of achievement ‚Äì solve it now or forever be lost in the annals of inadequacy.

The allure of Akin lies not just in its puzzles but in the open-ended nature of their solutions. Much like navigating the intricacies of human relationships, there's no one-size-fits-all approach. The freedom to chart your course, exploring multiple avenues, mirrors the complexity of societal interactions where conformity is an illusion and individuality reigns supreme.

Let's not forget the "Teleport"-tile ‚Äì a whimsical twist that adds a layer of unpredictability reminiscent of life's sudden plot twists. Just when you think you've got it all figured out, the game nonchalantly teleports your line to another point, a stark reminder of the capricious hand of fate.

And then there's the "Double Use"-tile, a devious contraption demanding a level of foresight and strategic thinking that rivals the Machiavellian intricacies of power dynamics. It's a lesson in resource management ‚Äì a skill often overlooked in the chaotic tapestry of modern existence.

In the end, Akin transcends the mere realm of entertainment. It's a metaphorical journey through the labyrinth of existence, where one continuous line symbolizes the inexorable march of time and the kaleidoscopic dance of human experience. So, draw your line, make things akin, and ponder the profound intricacies of a puzzle game that is, in essence, a mirror reflecting the convoluted masterpiece of life itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988376070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 1411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1406, 'last_played': 1700846730}
review:
[h1][b]A Good Puzzle Game![/b][/h1]

[b]What this game is:[/b] On one side a relaxing minimalist puzzle game, on the other side a timed and sometimes demanding puzzle game.   

[b]How does it work?[/b] You need to uniformize the colour of the blocks composing each setup by connecting them together.  There are always the same two colours: most setup are obviously pushing towards converting one colour or the other, some can go either way. Success is defined by having only one colour on the board, and allows you to go to the next setup. There are two sets of problems to solve: one "normal", the other one is "timed", both sets being similar setups, meaning you will solve 96 setups in each mode. 

[b]How does it perform?[/b] Very easy to play. This game is intuitive but requires sometimes some serious thinking, and progress is made at your own pace in the "normal" problems, and is constrained by time in the other mode.

[b]The good points:[/b] Simple, efficient and absorbing game.  It has a good accompanying music that can be shut off in the game settings if it hinders your concentration, and a simple and minimalistic design. Some of the setups are quite demanding, in particular in timed problems, but most problems are not that difficult. There are achievements, and getting them is relatively easy. Please note that in order to get 100% achievements, you will need to be able to solve all timed problems in a matter of 15 minutes, but thankfully you only need to replay some or all of the timed problems until the total solving time is below 15 minutes.  The game takes less than 60 MB on your HD, and will run on a 10 years old PC. The price asked of it is fair and worth what you will get out of it.  You should get a few good hours of play out of it, depending on your timed performance it may take more time to some people than others.  It has Steam Trading Cards.  

[b]The bad points:[/b] The mechanics of movements may prove to be a problem for some people.  The game can be played either through using a mouse or apparently a keyboard.  After having trouble using the mouse on some timed problems, I tried to switch to using the keyboard.  Unfortunately, everything I tried did not allow me to use my keyboard even though in the settings there is a place that is supposed to help by programming the usable keys on it.  Using the trackpad of a laptop did not work well at all.  I had to stick to using a mouse in order to complete the game at the cost of cramps in my hand and arm. There is a "Dark" setting that should allow you to reduce the brightness of the game (which may prove to be too bright to photosensitive people) but it does not work.  This makes the game appear unfinished or "unpolished": what is the point of having settings that do not work? Once you have finished the two groups of problems to solve, the game has been played through. This means that replay value is limited, and most people will not come back to this game before a long time, if at all.  

[b]My take on this:[/b] It is a good and sometimes challenging puzzle game. The music is good, the simple graphics help you concentrate, the mechanics of the game are intuitive.  For the basic price that is asked of it, you cannot go wrong. If you find it at a discount, it would be a pity not to grab it, as it is then very cheap while providing many good hours of gameplay.

For the price this is an excellent little game!

review:
Another minimalistic puzzle game, connect squares till the whole board is in one color. There are plenty of puzzles and some require thinking which is great, many of them can be completed in different ways, paths which adds to the positive part. Also a potato can run this game, it is created with Unity engine.

It has normal and time mode.
[b]YOU WILL NEED DEXTERITY[/b] as your mouse hand will start hurting if you are going for the timed achievement, to shave those precious seconds.

Music... ha! there is only one song on repeat, it is alright fits the game, but turn it down and play something of your own.

Downside there is no replayability, the puzzles are pre-fixed, well there is some if you are doing the timed one to reduce the taken time, and another thing the background option for dark one is broken, it changes nothing, so playing this in a dark room might be eye straining.

Has steam achievements and cards which is always a plus.

Did have fun and for the sale price totally worth the value and time spent!

[b]VERDICT 8/10[/b]
[h1]RECOMMENDED![/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197961546585', 'num_games_owned': 38, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1671667235}
review:
Minimalistic ‚Äûpuzzle game‚Äú that is fun, quite easy at the beginning and yet can be challenging.

The goal of the game is to finish each puzzle with a continuous line.

Sometimes easier said than done.

The game offers 96 different puzzles and levels of difficulty and is therefore quite extensive.

At the beginning, as expected, the puzzles are still quite easy and the paths are relatively clear, but that changes quickly and it becomes much more difficult.

Even if there are different ways to solve each puzzle, once you make a mistake you cannot undo it like in other games of this type and you have to start the level from the beginning.

If all this is (still) too easy for you, you can also try the time mode.
Here, too, this works relatively well at the lower levels, but becomes quite demanding at higher levels due to the time factor.

Really fun, can be challenging and keep you busy for a few hours.

review:
This review is specially made for those who like to get all the achievements in games and have this one in their backlog (minor spoilers ahead).

[b]Description:[/b]  
Akin is a minimalist 2D puzzle game where you need to plan a path that uses every square on the board of a given color. It offers a normal mode, without a time limit, and a timed mode where you need to think faster.

[b]Achievements:[/b]  
[b]How many:[/b] 9 Achievements.
[b]How much time:[/b] Around 7 hours.
[b]Game difficulty:[/b] Easy, the gameplay is simple and the puzzles only get longer and slightly more difficult as the game progresses.   
[b]Achievements‚Äô Difficulty:[/b] Easy. Finishing all the levels will grant most of the achievements. The hardest one will be to finish the timed mode in under 15 minutes, but it doesn't require a full playthrough, you can simply improve the times of each level until the total is below the limit.

[b]Overall opinion:[/b]  
Akin is a simple puzzle game that gets a bit repetitive since just two different features are added and the puzzles remain mostly the same, only the layout changes. Still, it won‚Äôt be too hard to complete and only requires a bit of hand dexterity for the timed mode.

review:
"Akin" is a basic, minimalist, mobile app tier "continuous line" puzzle where the objective is to put your finger on your iPhone screen and drag it through all the squares in a continuous line to fill them all in without touching the same square twice or taking your finger off your iPhone screen. 

This basically looks and feels like a Unity Asset flip.  The game only features minimalist 2D mobile phone tier "art", has locked resolution and controls, and all the other problems that typical mobile app shovelware has.  I don't know if this was even launched on mobile, but it's pretty obvious it was intended to be.

An important note: Big Black Bear are known asset flippers and have previously taken other developers work and put it on Steam in an attempt to scam gamers and get paid for someone else's effort.  

One example of Big Black Bear doing this is Factory Pirates, which is really the "[url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/3d/environments/historic/polygon-pirates-low-poly-3d-art-by-synty-92579]Polygon Pirates Low Poly 3D asset pack[/url]" asset, written by the actual developers, Synty Games.

Asset flips are harmful to the gaming industry.  They're nothing but cash grabs, and they harm genuine indie developers by reducing their visibility on Steam.  They make it harder for gamers to find decent games made by genuine game developers.  Because this game has all the same low quality as an asset flip, as well as the other problems with it, it's impossible to recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041511398', 'num_games_owned': 3714, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1652976591}
review:
Puzzle games that have one fundamental mechanic to make it easy to understand and pick up are some of the most interesting. Keeping in line with minimalism, the spaces you have to fill become larger and more oddly shaped. This gives you plenty of time to learn the ropes and get familiar with a few tricks that you'll keep using to fill in the edges and areas with gaps.

One thing I like is that there isn't a clear right or wrong way to solve each puzzle. There are more than one way to fill in all the squares on the grid. The tricky part is actually being able to do it.

There are 96 levels to burn through that won't take relatively long to do. Then you can try timed mode, which is just the 96 levels over again. However, the board is flipped, and you've only got a small amount of time to solve them in.

On another positive note, this game comes equipped with three catchy songs that amount to just under 8 minutes. This helps to maintain the game's enjoy-ability.

review:
Simple concept yet quite demanding game.
Akin is a simple looking production with nice pastel colors. It has a good color scheme and a nice sountrack.

Promo video explains whole mechanics. What can be difficult in this game? - You might ask.
Well, if you make the levels big, add portals and fields that can be used multiple times the level solution stops being that obvious. If you add a time limit it becomes fairly difficult. An achievement for solving all time trials in less than 15 minutes makes the game demanding.

The biggest con of the game is that it sometimes does not register quick moves of a mouse. 
Another thing that could be improved is changing levels - instead of coming back to a level menu the game always comes back to the main menu and requires choosing mode, set and finally the level we wanted. It is irritating in particular when one tries to improve their records in time mode.
There is also a lack of 'reply' button after solving a level.

Nonetheless I had a very good time with Akin, therefore I recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996964816', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1561906254}
review:
A simple colour in the tiles game, its all quite well implemented with functional graphics nice enough sound and music. 
For its price you get plenty of game play so I can recommend giving it a shot. 

However, it does have issues. Do you know whats challenging if you put a strict timer on? Literally anything, and this game leans far too heavily on that lazy mechanic. 

Whats more they can be really frustrating, not because they are particularly difficult but because the interface has problems with the speed of play required. Ive literally been left hovering over the next square along, mouse button down, which should mean the line keeps going but its just stuck in place because I moved to fast or some other glitch. So you have to go just fast enough to get within the time without going too fast to screw up the input. (Which is really hard on your hand as well, dont play this if you get RSI.)

It has enough thats good to justify giving it a go, but I do wish that instead of these cheap timed levels it had introduced some interesting new mechanics and made more of a puzzle game of itself rather than put the bulk of the game in how fast can you colour in the blocks.

review:
Bought this on sale for a buck. Roughly 3 or so hours of puzzle fun for a buck. Money well spent. 

My only con, going fast on time mode bugged me because either my mouse or the game disliked keeping up. This caused a repeat several times. A good thing most these puzzles do not take long to complete. 

I like the fact the added in elements into some of the puzzles were unneeded for many of the puzzles. I zoomed right around them.  

PS: The timed maps are A-H maps but rotated 180. Realized this halfway through the timed, so if you get stuck on a timed, don't fret! I=A, J=B, etc. Just jump back to the non-timed levels, figure out your pattern, and go use it on the timed ones.

review:
Akin is a simple puzzle game at its core where you have to draw a continuous line using your mouse, in order for all tiles to change colour. The game starts off easy and very relaxing, but gets harder after each level. However, it very gets too difficult in my opinion, but some little brain teasers are provided during the levels.
The timed levels, and the corresponding achievement, provide a nice challenge and can be considered a bit more difficult. 
At the time of writing I've spent almost seven hours on the game and almost completed it 100% in terms of achievements.

For the price, this fun, and amazing little puzzle game is a bargain in my opinion; which I can easily recommend to any fan of puzzle game enthusiast. The only criticism I have, is that sometimes the line you intend to draw is not properly registered if you move the mouse extremely fast. But this is hardly an issue in practise.

review:
[h1] Game Summary: [/h1] 
This puzzle game is rather straightforward, so what is shown in the trailer is pretty much all the game consists of.  Each stage is made up of squares, either blue, yellow, or both, and the objective is to turn all squares into the same color (or if they're all already one color, to inverse them).  This is completed by picking a starting square of one color, and dragging the mouse cursor over all the other squares of the same color in a continual line, without disruption or overlapping the same square again.  There are some mechanics that come up in certain stages that allow you to overlap a select square, but little else is introduced to change up the mechanics or gameplay.  Aside from a few cases where your pathway can deviate slightly, almost every stage has only a single solution.  


[h1] Pros: [/h1] 
‚Ä¢	There are quite a few levels in the game, between the two modes available to play through.  8 sets of 12 levels per mode, so 96 normal stages and 96 time trial stages.  
‚Ä¢	Though the levels do get more advanced over time, all but the most difficult stages at the end seem manageable.  The last few stages were quite large and winding.  
‚Ä¢	The sound effects and music can be muted in the options.  There was only one track in the entire game, so I muted it.  
‚Ä¢	The choice of colors was tolerable.  They didn't clash or strain the eyes.  


[h1] Cons: [/h1] 
‚Ä¢	The core mechanic of the game involves you dragging the mouse cursor over squares to change their color.  This movement should feel natural and easy to direct, but it seems stilted, unresponsive, and overly difficult.  It's easily the worst part of the game.  
‚Ä¢	Due to the poor controls, the time trial mode winds up being a bad pairing for the game.  Especially since it doesn't merely track your time to beat each stage, but puts a time limit on it.  If you're too slow, you fail and have to try again.  
‚Ä¢	Though the game adds a few mechanics to change up the gameplay, they aren't well used.  Sometimes there will be a square you can overlap, but the stage won't even need it.  That's probably why they weren't used more often.  
‚Ä¢	Considering how the stages were broken down so methodically, I'd have expected a central theme to them or something.  However, it seems to be entirely arbitrary.  The colors don't change, nor does the music.  


[h1] Conclusion: [/h1] 
The gameplay reminds me slightly of solving a maze, but without a pre-defined start and finish.  That's part of the puzzle, determining the route that needs to be taken, including which square you have to start from and end at.  However, unlike many mazes where you can either undo a bad turn and go back or there's enough margin for error in how you navigate the corridors, the way this game controls is unforgiving.  These issues would be tolerable, to some extent, if the game's controls felt more responsive and well-tuned, but they only wind up feeling rigid and difficult to work with.  

The difficulty in dragging through the squares as you intend becomes more of an obstacle than figuring out the right way to go, which makes the time trial mode a tiresome chore.  For those who play this game with a track pad, like me, it's not feasible to beat the last set of time trial stages.  I can't make the game function and cooperate enough with me to do it, when I should be zipping through the zigs and zags with a flourish.  I would have been bored of the game by the time I finished it otherwise, but still could recommend it as a diversion.  With how it controls though, I don't recommend this game to anyone because it's annoying and frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132503739', 'num_games_owned': 601, 'num_reviews': 548, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1512307338}
review:
[b]My playtime:[/b] 6.6h (based on steam, 100% achievements)
[b]Grindy Achievement:[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement:[/b] Yes (1 achievement).
[b]Difficult Achievement:[/b] No (there is one time based achievements though).
[b]Developer Response:[/b] Yes (~24h).

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Akin is a puzzle game where you have to change all the tiles into the same color. You can change the tile's color by drawing a line between each tiles and you can't draw a line to a tile that have been crossed before.

[h1]Music[/h1]
The music is relaxing for a puzzle game. It's great to listen for a long time. However, some of the music has static in it.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game's graphics are simple; it's mostly squares with colors. However, the game's assets break (as in.. placed incorrectly) under 600x400 resolution although the game offers resolution lower than that. The game also doesn't display the time that's used to beat the time mode level in lower resolution.

[h1]The game[/h1]
As i said before, the game requires you to change all tiles to a same color by drawing a line. At later levels, the game will also introduce two other special tiles that have their own usage. All of the game mechanics are explained perfectly on each levels.

The game has two modes: normal and time mode. The normal mode has a bigger and more difficult levels with no timer while the time mode has a less difficult levels with timer. In time mode, you need to beat the level before the timer runs out or you have to redo the level. The normal mode might fry your brain (i even need to take a break several times just to refresh my brain) because of its difficulty, especially on later levels. The time mode, in the other hand, requires you to "remember" how to solve the puzzle and move your mouse quickly. However, the game's movement is too slow for me in 1280x720 resolution and it becomes even slower after hitting the retry button several times that i have to switch to 600x400 resolution with the lowest graphic quality to beat the time mode in less than 15 minutes, which is required for an achievement.

Pros;
- 2 modes
- 96 + 96 levels

Cons:
- The cursor movement speed is very slow on higher resolution and after hitting reply button several times

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This is a great puzzle game with 2 modes in it.

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]Despite the cursor movement, the game is actually quite fun if you take a break here and there. If you like puzzle games, buy it on discount.[/i]
